items.title: scout breaks caching for django
items.body:
We gave scout a try and looked promising but then we quickly had to disable it on production.

Issue is that scout is adding a `Vary: Cookie` header which breaks caching



This normally happens when some code in django accesses the request.user object. I'm assuming scout is trying to add some meta data and accesses it causing this issue.

We've run into this problem ourselves in the past and the way around is it to look for the internal cached user on the request object. Like this:

```
    # going request.user will generate cookie vary headers, but since
    # we aren't changing the output based on this we want to see the user
    # without adding the header, so look for the lazy user
    if request and hasattr(request, '_cached_user'):
        # noinspection PyProtectedMember
        user = request._cached_user
```

I think if replaced the check for user here

https://github.com/scoutapp/scout_apm_python/blob/master/src/scout_apm/django/middleware.py#L139

items.title: PermissionError: [Errno 13] Permission denied: '/tmp/scout_apm_core/scout_apm_core-v1.2.9-x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/core-agent'
items.body:
Seeing this in our logs when trying to use scout.

also

```
/tmp/scout_apm_core/scout_apm_core-v1.2.9-x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/core-agent start --daemonize true --log-level info --socket /tmp/scout_apm_core/scout_apm_core-v1.2.9-x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/scout-agent.sock
```

I believe our issue is that we mount /tmp as tmpfs inside a docker and so doesn't have execute capabilites

How do we configure the location of this?

items.title: Add 'collect_remote_ip' setting
items.body: As reported by @cschneid on Slack, copying from the Ruby agent. Add a `collect_remote_ip` setting that disables the `user_ip` tag on traces.

items.title: Add RQ subclass of HerokuWorker
items.body: The "Using RQ on Heroku" docs section ( https://python-rq.org/patterns/ ) shows using a subclass of `Worker` specialized for Heroku. Unfortunateely using that, rather than the Scout RQ Worker subclass means that scout isn't instrumented. We should also provide a `ScoutHerokuWorker` class.

items.title: Core agent update to 1.2.9
items.body: We've had a few bug fixes and improvements with the CA. Please bump to 1.2.9 in python CA manager.

items.title: Django log levels are ignored by core agent
items.body:
No matter what I did to the Django log levels, I kept getting this message when running Django management tasks:

```
[2020-04-02T09:36:06][core_agent][INFO] Initializing logger with log level: Info
```

This is super annoying, because this causes programs in my crontab to start sending out lots of e-mails because previously quiet tasks would now start producing output.

After a lot of trial and error, I figured out that you can set `SCOUT_LOG_LEVEL` in Django settings to suppress this message.

This really should be fixed so the agent also honors the Django logging settings, or at least documented under the logging section in the Python documentation. It's really non-obvious that this the agent is a separate thing which ignores the Django logging settings.

items.title: Document Django support for request queueing
items.body: This would be very useful to have and it doesn't seem like a difficult thing to do; just read out the custom X-Request-Start header value from the request object.

items.title: Support Django BASE_DIR being a pathlib.Path
items.body: As per [my blog post today](https://adamj.eu/tech/2020/03/16/use-pathlib-in-your-django-project/), this is changing in Django 3.1 but users may already be changing it now.

items.title: Hide scout message about event draining
items.body:
When `log_level` is set to `ERROR` and logs are redirected to a log file through `log_file_path`, scout still logs a message like: `Scout draining 1 event for up to 2.0 seconds` on STDOUT, is it possible to remove this message from STDOUT?
Thank you!

items.title: Rename, document, and provide defaults for extra core agent configuration variables
items.body:
It's possible to set these config vars to change the way the core agent is launched:

* `log_level`
* `log_file`
* `socket_path`
* `config_file`

These should be prefixed with `core_agent` , like `core_agent_log_level`, and be documented. Would also be useful for the [logging guide](https://docs.scoutapm.com/#python-logging) to point to setting `core_agent_log_file` to capture the logs - by default they go to stdout, which is nowhere, and it makes debugging harder.

items.title: Default app name
items.body: Use a default app name like "Python App" rather than the empty string, so if users forget to set it it still appears on the consle.

items.title: Installation seems to be broken on python3.6.4
Ensure cutoff date is updated
items.body:
figure out when the cutoff date for ambiguous timestamps needs updating and either calculate it dynamically or add a unit test that fails when it needs adjusting.

https://github.com/scoutapp/scout_apm_python/blob/cf2246e6ff0dc1b69ffff25e10cd83782895ee27/src/scout_apm/core/web_requests.py#L149-L173

items.title: Remove SCOUT_LOG_LEVEL deprecation warning
items.body: The Heroku addon sets this environment variable automatically, and it can't vary based on language, so we shouldn't emit a deprecation warning (on Heroku only?) there since there's nothing users can do about it.

items.title: Require Celery app reference to read configuration
items.body:
We had a customer whose Celery tasks weren't reporting whilst their Django views were. It turns out they had configured in the Django settings file, which isn't applied when Celery runs. This is because it doesn't run "under" Django through `manage.py`, but separately through `celery worker`.

The django pattern is to use [Celery's `app.config_from_object`](https://docs.celeryproject.org/en/latest/reference/celery.html#celery.Celery.config_from_object) to read the Django settings. If we then read out of there for the scout settings, we would again allow shared configuration between the two.

This would need changing the Celery install process to take an `app` argument:

```python
app = celery.Celery(..)
...
scout_apm.celery.install(app)
```

We should work without this for backwards compatibility reasons, but throw a warninng when it's not passed as I predict this issue will appear repeatedly if we don't encourage users this way.

items.title: Add a "flush background thread" function
items.body:
To support one-off cron tasks that exit python when finished, we need to allow the background thread to finish its work. Currently, if the main thread exits, any in-flight data the background thread has is lost.

We should add a `flush_sync` or similar function that blocks until the background thread has sent whatever payloads it has over to the core agent.

items.title: Total span limit
items.body: For *really* long running background jobs it'd be possible to have a tracked request with so many spans it causes memory problems. Following #471 we should probably have a (very high) total cap on the number of captured spans.

items.title: Fix Jinja2 async integration
items.body:
Since https://github.com/pallets/jinja/issues/765 , Jinja2 only lazily imports and adds the `render_async` function that we instrument (since #398).

We need to update to only instrument at the point the `render_async` method becomes available.

items.title: Elasticsearch 7.5.1 changed positional arguments order
items.body:
Similar to #454, Elasticsearch 7.5.1 broke the test suite in another way.

https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch-py/issues/1099

items.title: Elasticsearch 'scripts_painless_context' method has disappeared
items.body:
The test suite is failing with the latest versions of elasticsearch-py since it seems the `scripts_painless_context` method has disappeared, whilst we try to instrument it.

I've filed an issue there: https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch-py/issues/1098

For now we should work around getting the test suite. If the method is intentionally removed, we should only try to instrument it on older versions.

items.title: Instrument non-index Elasticsearch client methods
items.body:
There are many methods on the `elasticsearch-py` client class that we aren't instrumenting, for example `ping()`, because they don't operate on an index.

We should capture all these calls too - I'm sure many applications have such calls that would be good to show on traces.

https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch-py/blob/master/elasticsearch/client/__init__.py

items.body:
I've tried to release version 2.9.0 twice but failed due to myabe a bug in twine, then a misconfiguration:

https://travis-ci.org/scoutapp/scout_apm_python/jobs/618637512

Should fix this and get 2.9.0 really shipped.

items.title: Don't crash the socket for unrecognized responses
items.body:
Before #400 when testing against the core agent I discovered the python agent crashes when the core agent doesn't return the expected response, like:

```
2019-11-25T18:08:49+0000 DEBUG  scout_apm.core.socket CoreAgentSocket thread exception: error('unpack requires a buffer of 4 bytes')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/chainz/Documents/Projects/scout_apm_python/src/scout_apm/core/socket.py", line 102, in run
    result = self._send(body)
  File "/Users/chainz/Documents/Projects/scout_apm_python/src/scout_apm/core/socket.py", line 171, in _send
    self._read_response()
  File "/Users/chainz/Documents/Projects/scout_apm_python/src/scout_apm/core/socket.py", line 183, in _read_response
    size = struct.unpack(">I", raw_size)[0]
struct.error: unpack requires a buffer of 4 bytes
```

I think we should make this more robust - we can avoid trying to unpack a response that isn't the right length. The Core agent was sending back nothing on parse error.

items.title: Huey Django integration
items.body: Thank so much for adding Huey integration (#362). When using Django the Huey task worker is started with a management command which is part of the Huey package. We are unable to modify the managements command. I suggest that a Django app is added to Scout which will connect to the Huey signals during the Django startup process.

items.title: Track all 5XX responses as errors
items.body:
Currently our web integrations we tend to insert ourselves as a "middleware" layer, and if an exception is raised below us, we catch it, track the current request as an error, then re-raise it. This allows the web framework to turn the exception into status code 5XX response.

Sometimes in web frameworks, a layer can be added below us that already catches exceptions and returns status code 5XX responses. For example, Django REST Framework does this - see #102.

We currently count such requests as successful. Instead we should tag them as errors.

items.title: Update psutil dependency to fix potential double-free error
items.body:
psutil, a Scout dependency, has an issue where it could theoretically be caused to double-free a pointer in error cases. None of the uses of psutil by Scout are with user-controlled data, so the most likely outcome is an interpreter crash, and not a security issue. (And we haven't seen crashes in the wild either).

We should update psutil as soon as a new release is out, although it doesn't look to be released as of writing this issue.

References:

https://app.snyk.io/vuln/SNYK-PYTHON-PSUTIL-483082

https://github.com/giampaolo/psutil/pull/1616/commits/29815d3a144a4f8a48f91e6d849ff4ba85f69cb1

https://github.com/giampaolo/psutil/pull/1616

https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2019-18874

items.title: Instrument rq
items.body:
RQ is a popular task queue: https://python-rq.org/

We should have an integration just like we do other task queues.

items.title: Stop using utcnow
items.body:
`datetime.utcnow()` should probably be avoided according to this article:

https://blog.ganssle.io/articles/2019/11/utcnow.html

It might not affect the way timing works in scout, but anyway the rewrite should be quite small.

items.title: Update for Starlette 0.13
items.body:
Starlette 0.13 will make a number of changes, such as to the recommended way of adding middleware: https://github.com/encode/starlette/pull/704

Once it's released we should update for those changes, but continue to also test the old way.

items.title: Add Huey integration
items.body: [Huey](https://huey.readthedocs.io/en/latest/) is a relatively popular task queue, and we've had at least one enquiry for it. We should support it.

items.title: List on Starlette Third Party Packages
items.body: After #349 is released, we should make a PR to Starlette requesting listing on their "third party packages" page.

items.title: Instrument Starlette authentication
items.body:
Starlette has a basic authentication framework: https://www.starlette.io/authentication/

We should probably copy what we do for Django here, tagging user ID's/ display names on traces.

items.title: Instrument Starlette background tasks
items.body: Starlette supports [background tasks](https://www.starlette.io/background/). We should instrument these as background transactions.

items.title: Test/instrument asynchronous Jinja2 rendering
items.body: Jinja2 supports an asynchronous render mode. We should add tests against it and if necessary  extend the existing instrumentation.

items.title: Make AppMetadata.data more robust
items.body:
Currently we use all-or-nothing semantics to find and send the app metadata. This is pretty useless as a single failure prevents all the other data being gathered. Instead we could do [more limited try/except clauses](https://adamj.eu/tech/2019/10/02/limit-your-try-clauses-in-python/) to allow us to send *something* even if some fields are empty.

Core Agent API docs: https://github.com/scoutapp/core-agent-api#application-metadata

items.title: Rewrite exec calls
items.body: Currently the elasticsearch and pymongo instruments rely on `exec()` to create functions. This is orders of magnitude slower than using inner functions, more fragile, and prevents inspection by our code quality tools. We should rewrite to use inner functions for their generation.

items.title: SQLAlchemy executemany not detected in hooks
items.body: In the Django ORM integration, we record `executemany` calls as the `SQL/Many` operation, but this is missing in the SQLAlchemy integration.

items.title: Instrument hug
items.body: Hug was reported used by 1% of developers in the [Python developers survey 2018](https://www.jetbrains.com/research/python-developers-survey-2018/). We should support it.

items.title: Instrument CherryPy
items.body: CherryPy was reported used by 3% of developers in the [Python developers survey 2018](https://www.jetbrains.com/research/python-developers-survey-2018/). We should support it.

items.title: Improve tastypie support
items.body: Currently some [Django Tastypie](https://django-tastypie.readthedocs.io/en/latest/) views are named simply `tastypie.resources` in their operation name. We can probably find better names, and maybe support some Tastypie specific tags!

items.title: Metadata should have language / language_version fields
items.body:
Standardizing metadata between the various agents - put a fixed `python` string in `language`, and  the version (`3.4.1` or whatever) in `language_version`

Keep the existing fields for now. Need to ensure that the CoreAgent handles them nicely when missing.

items.title: Switch to importlib.metadata for package versions
items.body:
Python 3.8 comes with the new standard library [module `importlib.metadata`](https://docs.python.org/3.8/library/importlib.metadata.html). This is the new de-facto way of discovering installed package versions.

For older versions there's the [`importlib-metadata` backport](https://importlib-metadata.readthedocs.io/en/latest/).

We currently use `pkg_resources` to do this, we'd be better off long term switching to the backport and standard library module. The backport supports down to Python 2.7 so it'll work for everything we do.

items.title: Use wrapt for all monkey patching
items.body: Rather than the included `monkey` module based on [proxytypes](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/ProxyTypes), use the de facto standard [wrapt](https://pypi.org/project/wrapt/)

items.title: Samplers thread race condition
items.body: The current samplers thread code has a number of race conditions and missing context manager usage of the lock that could manifest as broken behaviour. This could also end up failing in an async context as will be implemented in #285 .

items.title: Generic WSGI integration
items.body:
The Odoo framework in #232 seems a bit niche to build custom instrumentation for, but it wouldn't be hard for users to integrate a custom WSGI wrapper. This would also give us a baseline for all other frameworks we don't support, and inform the creation of a generic ASGI wrapper (started in #285).

The easiest way to build a generic WSGI integration, avoiding duplicating WSGI parsing code, is to depend on Werkzeug. We already have some functions for tracking based on Werkzeug `Request`s as deduplicated in #290 .

items.title: Possible to ignore transaction by name?
items.body:
We recently updated and started using #129. It is working great so far (for our graphql setup) but I was wondering if it was possible to add names to `SCOUT_IGNORE` and have it ignore the transaction by name?

We have a few auto-fetching requests similar to `/health` but are Queries in graphql. It would be great to have a way to ignore these!

items.title: Don't log scout key
items.body: Currently we log the scout key from configuration and in the register method at startup. Security conscious companies don't want license keys in their log files. We should avoid logging the key, though perhaps a hash or a substring could be useful.

items.title: Error with warnings in tests
items.body:
Currently our tests output a number of warnings from our dependencies. If we could ignore the known ones that our dependencies need to solve, we could then promote any warnings that do appear to errors. This would prevent us causing warnings to be raised for our users, e.g. the one fixed in #283. 

See [pytest docs](https://docs.pytest.org/en/latest/warnings.html).

items.title: Report error requests on Pyramid
items.body: Currently if an error occurs in a Pyramid request, we don't report it. Error cases can be just as useful to see so we should try and do this. It looks like it's possible by rearranging the existing code.

items.title: Deprecation warning thrown without using a config
items.body:
I'm seeing this deprecation warning even though I have not configured the agent in any way.

```
The config name 'log_level' is deprecated - please use the new name 'core_agent_log_level' instead.
```

items.title: Config value `log_level` does not seem to get applied to the python logging library
items.body:
We have a flask app running the latest 2.5.0 version of Scout APM. I have tried setting the `log_level` via an ENV variable and via the flask app config. Both methods actually set the value properly, but the logging module seems to ignore the value.

Confirmed this when I removed all custom settings, the default value should be `INFO` but we are seeing several `DEBUG` lines from scout in our logs.

I fixed this manually by setting the `log_level` via:

```
import logging

scout_logger = logging.getLogger('scout_apm')
scout_logger.setLevel('INFO')
```

Is this a known issue or am I configuring it improperly?

items.title: Config to capture query string, not just path
items.body:
When a request comes in, we capture `request.path`, which doesn't appear to capture any query string.

We should match the Ruby agent:
* Default to capturing the entire path and query string
* Config to not capture query string https://docs.scoutapm.com/#uri_reporting

items.title: Allow configuration of 'hostname'
items.body:
A customer has a setup where all of their servers have the same value for their hostnames. This causes the nodes table in our UI to merge all of their info.

* add a configuration value
* send that to Core Agent at startup.

Then there is a Core Agent task to pass that data along correctly.

items.title: Warn about wrong values for SCOUT_AGENT_TRIPLE
items.body: Follow-on to #239 - it's easy to override `SCOUT_AGENT_TRIPLE` to a wrong value. We should add some validation here with a log message if it looks wrong.

items.title: Add support for Dramatiq
items.body:
Could we investigate the feasibility of adding support for the Dramatiq background job library?

https://dramatiq.io/

We have only had the one request for it as far as I am aware. But if is not a huge job then it would be beneficial to have going forward.

items.title: Use Django 2.0+ DB instrumentation hook
items.body:
Rather than monkey-patching, use the built-in instrumentation on Django 2.0+:

https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/2.0/topics/db/instrumentation/

items.title: Core Agent inheriting and holding open sockets from parent
items.body:
Reported via Slack:

```

Mike O'Toole 9:12 AM
hey there -- are there any instructions available on installing/starting the core-agent separately from a django app?
cschneid:scout-orange: 9:13 AM
@Mike O'Toole - the binary gets downloaded to /tmp/scout_apm_core/… and has a help command.
Mike O'Toole 9:13 AM
we're running into an issue where the core-agent process seems to hang on to the ports that are uWSGI is binding when it first starts up. Then when we try to restart our uWSGI process, it tries to bind the ports again, and it can't because the core-agent process has still got them
cschneid:scout-orange: 9:14 AM
That is odd, it’s a totally different process, so shouldn’t ever have access to port file descriptors.
Mike O'Toole 9:15 AM
yeah -- that's what i thought too, but looking at lsof this is what im seeing:
core-agen 23301         chuck-uwsgi    8u  IPv4 7817953      0t0  TCP *:3031 (LISTEN)
core-agen 23301         chuck-uwsgi    9u  IPv4 7817954      0t0  TCP *:8080 (LISTEN)
cschneid:scout-orange: 9:15 AM
ok, well that’s not intended… :slightly_smiling_face:
Mike O'Toole 9:15 AM
3031/8080 are the ports that uWSGI is binding
cschneid:scout-orange: 9:16 AM
For now, you’re looking for core-agent start --socket-path <match the default, or the explicit config> 
Mike O'Toole 9:16 AM
sweet, thanks
cschneid:scout-orange: 9:17 AM
the default socket path is:
    def derive_socket_path(self):
        return "{}/{}/core-agent.sock".format(
            self.config.value("core_agent_dir"),
            self.config.value("core_agent_full_name"),
which would be something like: /tmp/scout_apm_core/scout_apm_core-latest-x86_64-apple-darwin/core-agent.sock
I’m really confused by the core agent holding onto those ports. We launch via             subprocess.check_call( ...  which I suppose would maintain file descriptors?
If close_fds is true, all file descriptors except 0, 1 and 2 will be closed before the child process is executed. (POSIX only). The default varies by platform: Always true on POSIX. 
from the docs.
sounds like it should have closed the socket handles?
Mike O'Toole 9:22 AM
hmmm weird
cschneid:scout-orange: 9:22 AM
What version of python are you on? I can try to reproduce
Mike O'Toole 9:24 AM
python 2.7.6
ahh, here's someone having a related issue with uWSGI

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/48376664/uwsgi-subprocess-create-a-new-process-the-socket-close-wait

sounds like that config option is what we need
cschneid:scout-orange: 9:25 AM
ok, the docs I shared were from 3.5, I wonder if that behavior changed
```

items.title: Scout maintaining lock during Heroku Python Buildscript
items.body:
Hi Team,

This regards an issue we've encountered deploying Scout onto Heroku. We use Heroku config vars (environment variables) to control features within our Django app.

We found that by having the SCOUT_MONITOR variable set to True the compile never finished. We discovered that having Scout disabled and then enabling it after the build worked.

My thinking is that the Scout application runs and then maintains a lock so the compile process waits until it times out.

We overcame this by adding some logic to detect if the app is in the build step and adjusting SCOUT_MONITOR accordingly.

We are not using the Heroku integred Scout (yet!- evaluating the trial)

items.title: Improve testing by using pytest fixtures
items.body:
Just FYI, you can improve your testing UX by using pytest fixtures:

Current test:

```python
def test_core_agent_permissions_custom():
    ScoutConfig.set(core_agent_permissions=770)
    config = ScoutConfig()
    try:
        assert 0o770 == config.core_agent_permissions()
    finally:
        ScoutConfig.reset_all()
```

Improved? test:

```python
import pytest

from scout_apm.core.config import ScoutConfig


@pytest.fixture(scope="module")
def reset_config():
    """ Reset the config before each test.  """
    ScoutConfig.reset_all()


def test_core_agent_permissions_custom():
    ScoutConfig.set(core_agent_permissions=770)
    config = ScoutConfig()
    assert 0o770 == config.core_agent_permissions()
```
That way, the test author just worries about the test and the fixture takes care of making sure the config is pristine before each test.

Lots of other options for fixtures: https://docs.pytest.org/en/latest/fixture.html

items.title: Django. Disable statistics partially
items.body:
For example, I want to collect statistics for all `/api/*` views and ignore it for website views.

Is there a correct way to do it?

The only way that I can think is clone this app and change middleware manually, but maybe there is some configuration that I'm missing.

Thank you.

items.title: CoreAgentSocket exception on _send: timeout('timed out',)
items.body:
With [this demo app](https://github.com/itsderek23/bakerydemo), I see the following in the log after every-other-request I trigger in the browser:

```
CoreAgentSocket exception on _send: timeout('timed out',)
```

That said, it appears that every request I trigger does appear in the Scout UI. This is the log as I trigger 2 requests:

* [Python agent log](https://gist.github.com/itsderek23/9cb6b28faa4e2abad573812c865c14b8)
* [Core Agent](https://gist.github.com/itsderek23/be45ddb7ccdb65f5cd374373064c97dc)

To setup the app, I followed [this set of instructions](https://github.com/itsderek23/bakerydemo#setup-with-virtualenv).

As specified, I run the app via `./manage.py runserver`.

I setup a `.env` file with:

```
DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE=bakerydemo.settings.local
SCOUT_KEY=KEY
SCOUT_LOG_FILE=core.log 
SCOUT_LOG_LEVEL=trace
``` 

As an easy first step, it might be worthwhile testing this against any Django app with `./manage.py runserver` running with `DEBUG = True`.

items.title: Fails if settings.BASE_DIR is not set
items.body:
https://github.com/scoutapp/scout_apm_python/blob/6d805805170580ab8fcab98ce7ad96ac6866325d/src/scout_apm/django/config.py#L15

`BASE_DIR` is not a required Django setting. It may not exist for a project and if it doesn't, the project initialization fails once scout is installed.

items.title: Add Python 3.7 to Travis builds
items.body: Travi's linux image is Trusty by default which cannot run 3.7. They should now have a Xenial image that we can use. Refer to https://github.com/travis-ci/travis-ci/issues/9069

items.title: Build core-agent for Alpine Linux
items.body:
The binary component of the agent doesn't launch on Alpine linux (or likely any musl based linux).

We need to create a new CI build for it, and ensure that platform detection works as expected on musl systems.

items.title: Ignoring children spans where instrumentation libraries overlap
items.body:
ElasticSearch uses urllib3 underneath the hood to make the network calls to the server. This causes the trace time to be attributes mostly to HTTP rather than Elasticsearch span:

![screenshot 2018-07-20 09 39 04](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/102774/43011692-74a44b06-8c01-11e8-8433-6ccb99e9e0ff.png)

We need an equivalent of our Ruby agent's `ignore_children` for spans.

items.title: ElasticSearch naming
items.body:
When doing a simple document get with ES:

```
    from elasticsearch import Elasticsearch
    es = Elasticsearch()
    es.get(index="my-index", doc_type='post', id=1)
```

The agent captures the span name as `Elasticsearch/Unknown`. We patch the `Transport.perform_request` method where we don't have an explicit operation name:

```
>>> args[1]
'/my-index/post/1'
>>> args
('GET', '/my-index/post/1')
>>> kwargs
{'params': {}}
```

We may need to add another instrumentation point higher up in the ES library to capture this name correctly.
